Author: hugh
Content:
Building great universities and the free and open societies necessary to support them would be an even better plan.

Cambodia has world wonders. Singapore doesn't.

Author: helveticaman
Content: I've had access to alcohol since I was really small, but I never saw much in it.  When I got to US to go to college, everyone was crazy about alcohol...it was really weird.  To me, it was like seeing adults go to chuck e cheese every day.

Author: gruseom
Content: I know of two things that help. One is exercise, which lots of people have mentioned here. The other is meditation. My brother-in-law suffered badly from insomnia for years and says it made the biggest difference out of all the things he tried.

Author: gruseom
Content: Alcohol induces wakefulness in the second half of sleep, so this is a bad idea. (There are many sources on this. I found http://alcoholism.about.com/cs/alerts/l/blnaa41.htm in a quick search.)

Author: briansmith
Content: I agree that it makes sense to prohibit the distribution of modified copies, but it is usually better to let people modify the software as long as they keep those modifications internal.

Author: cperciva
Content: It sounds to me like joining an open source project fits those goals far more than joining a startup does.

Author: Hexstream
Content: I understand your concerns but I'm also generally against holding back technological progress as a way to slow down the roadmap to the inevitable bad things that will result alongside the good ones.

Author: hugh
Content:
Well no, asymmetric warfare is any warfare where the two parties differ substantially in strength. In Iraq at the moment, for instance, we're trying to kill the enemy while the enemy doesn't seem to care whether they kill our soldiers or random civilians, but it would remain asymmetric even if the enemy would be so kind as to restrict themselves to trying to kill our soldiers.

Unless you're saying that the enemy in Iraq counts as "civilians" because they're not part of any proper and recognized army, but that's a rather point-missing definition of "civilian", since the defining characteristic of a civilian is whether they're engaging in combat.

Author: royty
Content:
For all non open-source projects it makes sense to have a no-derivative works license. You would be putting yourself out of business without it.

Awesome script, I'll definitely be using it in some projects.

Author: radu_floricica
Title: Ask HN: Sales strategy for a custom software startup
Content:
We're 6 month into a custom software startup. The business model is simple: make from scratch a software for a medium company, develop constantly and charge monthly. It worked great for me as a freelancer (and for my customers as well) and I'm trying to scale it together with an investor (former customer who got rich).

The technical side is ok, in about 6 month we have a good team and a couple of more apps. Last month we really started to look for new customers, but it goes a lot more slowly then expected. We have two big problems: First is the way we approach a new client - I dislike spam in any way and most things we can try are email/phone/snail mail spam. Also they don't work very well. The other is the difficulty of explaining the concept. Some like both the idea of custom software and of selling is as a service, but most find them too foreing.

Any ideas on future sales strategy?

Author: ph0rque
Content: Whatever you pay for the licence, you don't get to modify the code (unless I'm misunderstanding what "no-derivative" means). That's what "de-excited" me about it.

Author: daniel-cussen
Content: It'd be just like the last five centuries.  Robots would be the new guns.  Not that that's good, but it sure isn't new.

Author: radu_floricica
Content: It only goes to show work relationships in general should not be set in stone. It's the basic rule of fiability... if each has a 40% chance of failing, the pair has only 35% chance for success. Ergo, prepare for your partner's failure just as you would for your own, or more.

Author: noonespecial
Content: I know all of the arguments. Saving American lives etc. They sound good. I love robotics but I still recoil at the thought of first-world technological giants deploying semi-autonomous, or ever fully autonomous machines to kill vastly outmatched humans in third world nations at no risk to themselves. It just begs for abuse. If not now, certainly in the future.
